sections.title: Why Smart People Make Dumb Money Decisions
sections.subtitle: Understanding and overcoming common psychological traps in investing and spending

sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: Common cognitive biases that affect financial decisions
Strategies to recognize and mitigate these biases
Building systems to make more rational financial choices

sections.title: Cognitive Biases in Finance
sections.content: Our brains use mental shortcuts that can lead to irrational financial decisions. These biases are evolutionary adaptations that served us well in other contexts but often hurt us financially. Recognizing these patterns is the first step toward making better choices.

points.title: Loss Aversion
points.description: We feel the pain of losses more than the pleasure of gains, leading to holding losing investments too long.

points.title: Confirmation Bias
points.description: We seek information that confirms our existing beliefs, ignoring contradictory evidence in financial decisions.

points.title: Herding Behavior
points.description: Following the crowd in investment decisions, often leading to buying high and selling low.

sections.title: Overconfidence in Financial Knowledge
sections.content: Many investors overestimate their ability to beat the market, leading to excessive trading and poor performance. Studies show that active traders underperform buy-and-hold investors.

sections.title: Mitigating Behavioral Biases
sections.content: Create rules-based systems for financial decisions, like automatic investing or predetermined sell rules. Use checklists for major financial decisions, seek diverse opinions, and maintain an investment journal to track your decision-making process and learn from mistakes.

sections.title: Reduce Bias in Your Decisions
steps: Identify one bias you've exhibited in past financial decisions
Create a simple rule or checklist to counteract that bias
Start an investment journal to track your decision-making process
Discuss major financial decisions with someone who has a different perspective

sections.title: Awareness Without Self-Judgment
sections.content: Everyone has biases - they're part of being human. Focus on creating systems that work around your biases rather than trying to eliminate them entirely.
